docs.lead_paragraph: Only the magnitude of disaster a few yards away could have eclipsed the painful story of the former Federal Office Building at 90 Church Street. This imposing one-million-square-foot Art Deco structure was handsomely renovated in the late 1990's by Boston Properties, which holds the master lease. Until Sept. 11, it housed nearly 3,000 employees of the United States Postal Service, the New York City Housing Authority and the Legal Aid Society. Today, it is empty and sealed off. No one knows when it will reopen.

headline.main: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Downtown Manhattan; A Big Victim Is Still Empty After a Year

docs.abstract: Federal Office Building at 90 Church Street in Manhattan is still empty and sealed off, permeated by contaminants, including lead, mercury and asbestos, from collapse of 7 World Trade Center and twin towers; Insignia/ESG says building is last of big office towers around ground zero that remains vacant; map; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Only the magnitude of disaster a few yards away could have eclipsed the painful story of the former Federal Office Building at 90 Church Street.    This imposing one-million-square-foot Art Deco structure was handsomely renovated in the late 1990's...

docs.lead_paragraph: Nassau County officials estimated today that a surge of voluntary retirements would help shrink the county's work force by a 10th, or nearly 1,000 jobs, by year's end. But they warned that a worsening fiscal crisis might force the county to lay off 200 people beyond that. Reducing the payroll is a major part of a fiscal recovery plan under County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi. He took office Jan. 1, vowing to solve Nassau's chronic budget crisis, which prompted a state bailout and the imposition of a fiscal review board in 2000.

headline.main: Nassau Work Force to Shrink, But Suozzi Warns of Layoffs

docs.abstract: Nassau County officials estimate that surge of voluntary retirements would help shrink country's work force by tenth, or nearly 1,000 jobs, by year's end; but they warn that worsening fiscal crisis might force county to lay off 200 people beyond that (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Health Department has increased the Medicaid payment to medical facilities for mammographies. As of Oct. 1, the reimbursement for a screening of both breasts will rise to $90 from $51. Kristine Smith, a Health Department spokeswoman, said health care providers have complained about losing money on the screenings. About 64,000 Medicaid patients received such tests between October 1999 and September 2000, she said. Ms. Smith said the department was expecting the number to increase by 10 percent once the measure takes effect. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Change In Mammogram Payments

docs.abstract: New York State Health Department increases Medicaid payment for mammographies in response to complaints from health care providers about losing money on screenings (S)

byline.original: By Stacy Albin (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

docs.lead_paragraph: Never has so much money been raised with so little effort. The roughly $2.7 billion raised for charity in the months after Sept. 11 set a record for philanthropy. Within just 24 hours of the attacks, the American Red Cross raised more than $1 million, and ultimately almost 300 charities were created to address the disaster in some way. Many who gave had never given before.

headline.main: A Flood of Money, Then a Deluge of Scrutiny for Those Handing It Out

docs.abstract: Record $2.7 billion was raised for charity in months after Sept 11; American Red Cross raises more than $1 million within 24 hours of atttacks, and ultimately almost 300 charities were created to address disaster in some way; but for all the good it has brought, philanthropic response to Sept 11 has perhaps forever changed nature and expectations of charity, setting precedents that will most likely bring discord; never have press, donors and regulators given such scrutiny to charity; several principles that have long served as bedrock of American charity--that it should benefit needy, that it should be distributed equitably, that it should not aid illegal activity--were either scrapped or set aside in rush (L)
docs.snippet: Never has so much money been raised with so little effort. The roughly $2.7 billion raised for charity in the months after Sept. 11 set a record for philanthropy.    Within just 24 hours of the attacks, the American Red Cross raised more than $1...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the World Trade Center towers fell, they took more with them than human lives. A huge segment of the downtown economy collapsed with the falling steel and concrete, and the disaster encompassed far more than the large financial firms that are most often identified with the Sept. 11 attacks. The trade center was home to hundreds of diverse companies, a polyglot village spanning everything from Asian food importers to graphic designers to dentists. Many had inhabited the towers for decades.

headline.main: For Towers' Refugee Businesses, a Year of Struggle and Change

docs.abstract: World Trade Center was home to hundreds of diverse companies, polyglot village spanning everything from Asian food importers to graphic designers to dentists; many had inhabited towers for decades; these companies, more than half of which had fewer than 20 employees, became refugees on Sept 11; some have folded, others have eked out living in kitchens and basements; some have relocated to other states, while others insist on staying within few blocks of ground zero; detailed look at fate of complex's many tenants in last year; photos; charts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: EUNIVERSE, Los Angeles, an interactive entertainment network, said it had acquired the assets of privately held ResponseBase, Los Angeles, an online marketing company. Terms were not disclosed. INVERNESS MEDICAL INNOVATIONS INC., Waltham, Mass., a provider of health and nutritional products for women, said it had agreed to buy Ostex International, Seattle, a medical technology company, for about $36.8 million in stock.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health maintenance organizations serving 200,000 elderly and disabled people said today that they would pull out of Medicare next year, raising to 2.4 million the number of beneficiaries who have been dropped by H.M.O.'s since 1998. The new data came from the American Association of Health Plans, a trade association for the managed care industry, which surveyed its members. Such surveys have been accurate in the past.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s For 200,000 Pulling Out Of Medicare

docs.abstract: Health maintenance organizations serving 200,000 elderly and disabled people will pull out of Medicare in 2003, raising to 2.4 million the number of beneficiaries who have been dropped by HMO's since 1998; American Association of Health Plans, which bases estimate on survey of members, says plans are being forced out of Medicare market by inadequate federal payments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 29, 1999, a 31-year-old architecture student in Germany named Mohamed Atta, unknown to the world but already determined to strike an unforgettable blow against those he believed to be his enemies, boarded Turkish Airlines Flight 1662 from Istanbul to Karachi, Pakistan. Mr. Atta took at least a couple of days to reach his final destination: a training camp in Afghanistan run by Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's sprawling international terrorist organization.

headline.main: On Plotters' Path to U.S., A Stop at bin Laden Camp
headline.kicker: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PIECES OF A PUZZLE

docs.abstract: Investigators still struggle year later to fill significant gaps in narrative of planning, preparation and connections between leaders of most devastating foreign terrorist attack on US soil on September 11; disclose that Mohamed Atta, alleged ringleader of hijacking plot, traveled to Al Qaeda training camp in Afghanistan in 1999 and met with Osama bin Laden; believe he was accompanied by others and that they discussed undertaking terrorist operation with bin Laden; new information, much gleaned from interviews with captured Al Qaeda members, provides strongest evidence that bin Laden personally supported plotters; article details Atta's links with hijackers; details years of plotting in Europe and Asia, including hijackers' extensive pilot training in US, that culminated in September 11 attacks; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Aon, the world's second-largest insurance broker, was reorganizing itself, concentrating its operations in four centers around the country. The first was at ground zero.

headline.main: Aon Is Moving to New Offices, but Will Avoid Tall Buildings

docs.abstract: Article on scene at Aon's operations in New York one year after Sept 11 terrorist attacks at World Trade Center cost world's second-largest insurance broker lives of 175 employees; Aon's main operations in New York have been restored and company's brokers and consultants are preparing to move into new offices in Midtown Manhattan and in downtown financial district; many employees have decided not to work in New York; chief executive Patrick G Ryan comments (M)
docs.snippet: A year ago, Aon, the world's second-largest insurance broker, was reorganizing itself, concentrating its operations in four centers around the country.    The first was at ground zero.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''New employees come up to me and say, 'You know, people here have issues,' '' says Howard W. Lutnick, the chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, reflecting on life today inside Cantor, the bond trading firm that lost more people in the Sept. 11 attacks than any other American company. ''And I say, 'I know. Me, too.' '' An instant later, his rueful smile is gone: ''We've been through the worst of circumstances, the worst of circumstances,'' he said in an interview last week. ''But we're still here.''

headline.kicker: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE BOND TRADER

docs.abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald, which lost 658 people working in north tower of World Trade Center on Sept 11, is on track to earn just under $100 million in year that began last Oct 1, dominant player in bond markets once again, with solid backing from its banks, tenacious grip on its valuable software patents and new offices in Midtown Manhattan; firm now occupies several comfortably low floors of building overlooking Lexington Avenue and 57th Street; Cantor has narrowed its business focus, relying more on electronic bond-trading technology developed by its affiliate e-Speed, and on its growing stock trading business, which serves big professional investors; chairman Howard W Lutnick, chief administrative officer Heidi Olson and president Philip Marber comment; photos (M)
